data.text: Bikepacking Trips without a Helmet?

Hopefully this doesn't cause controversy but does anyone here do bikepacking trips without a helmet? I grew up skateboarding which has a bit of an anti-helmet culture which might be why I haven't bothered getting one for cycling yet. Most of the time it doesn't feel necessary as I'm mostly off road not going super fast but there's been one or two times going down a steep gravel hill where I've thought it might be a good idea to wear one. Would be interested to see how many people don't bother with it though.

I don't always wear a helmet when I'm nipping to the shops along a flat road or things like that, but if I'm doing anything hilly I always wear a helmet. I came off on a bikepacking trip riding down hill when I hit a runnel at a funny angle, got concussion even with a helmet on, not worth thinking about what would have happened without a helmet. Only got one noggin, protect it ‚úå

data.text: My worst injury happened at slow speed on a simple off road trail. I slipped on a hidden wet root and gashed my knee on a hidden rock. I needed stitches and there was so much leaf mulch underneath the stitches, I needed most of the skin covering my kneecap removing so my patella bursar (kneecap membrane) could be scrubbed. I was in a trauma ward for 2 days, a normal ward for 5, had no bend in my knee for 2 months (they stretched my thigh skin down and my shin skin up and sewed it together) and was off the bike for 3 months. It was a stupid and simple accident and the only reason my knee got gashed was due to the position of the rock when I crashed. If it was positioned by my head, I would have been fine as the helmet would have prevented all that guff! Skateboarding you fall differently to a bike, plus concrete is more predictable than off-road terrain, so the no helmet thing has more stiction (although still seen some nasty head injuries in skating!) but it‚Äôs not worth the risk in a bike especially if you‚Äôre miles away from home

Went OTB full somersault n cracked my helmet in two up the back. Also got concussion and whiplash. If that had been my head I wouldn‚Äôt have walked away. My mum had a brain injury/bleed and it was the most debilitating thing I have ever seen. Fit and healthy to paralysed down one side and unable to speak, 24 hour care needed. data.author: Peter Oag

data.text: Offroad you really want to be wearing a good quality helmet. Especially if you are a long way from help and riding on paths that are not busy with other users. Paths that you have never ridden before can often throw up unexpected surprises. Even at slow speeds you will still fly a good distance if you come off. I had a wee flight last week, over the bars on a dirt trail and flew head first straight into a giant patch of nettles. Bike was ok. As an MTB trail/downhill enthusiast wearing a helmet and protection is second nature on the rough stuff. No matter how good you are or how dialed in your trail skills are you will still crash from time to time even on relatively easy trails. It is an occupational hazard of the sport.
data.author: Jim McNeil

data.text: I was once walking when a guy on his bike was cycling past with a shopping bag on his handlebar. An apple in his bag went through the spokes and stopped the wheel dead. He wasn't going fast but went over the handlebar and landed on his head... without a helmet. There was a crack from his eye socket going upwards and another one going backwards and his forehead above the eye was completely flat with blood pumping out of the cracks. One of the worst things I have ever seen. He was still conscious when the ambulance arrived but I know a month later he hadn't picked up his bike. Not worth the risk. Always wear a helmet.
